Authors:
Sushma V Ponukumati, Monica Elliott, Elizabeth A Des
Jardin
Title:
Comparison of Secreted In Xylem (SIX) Genes in Two Fusarium
Wilt Pathogens of Ornamental Palms
Keywords:
Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. canariensis, Fusarium oxysporum
f. sp. palmarum, Arecaceae, Horizontal Gene Transfer
Abstract:
Fusarium oxysporum ff. spp. canariensis (Foc) and palmarum
(Fop) cause lethal Fusarium wilt on ornamental palms. Foc infects
Phoenix canariensis and has a worldwide presence, whereas Fop primarily
infects Washingtonia robusta and Syagrus romanzoffiana and is currently
restricted to Florida (USA). A PCR based screening was used to detect
and compare the Secreted in Xylem (SIX) gene profile among Fop (33) and
Foc (32) isolates obtained in the USA. SIX1, SIX7, SIX10 and SIX12 were
detected in most Foc isolates, with minimal sequence polymorphism,
except for SIX12. SIX8 and SIX9 were detected in all Fop isolates, with
no sequence polymorphism. SIX10 was also present in seven of the Fop
isolates, with sequences matching those of Foc. Phylogenetic trees were
constructed using sequences from this study and previously derived
sequences from Foc isolates obtained in Australia, Canary Islands and
Japan. The topology of housekeeping EF-1α gene indicated Foc is
polyphyletic, with the Australian isolates separating into a distinct
group from all other Foc isolates. However, the topologies of SIX1, SIX7
and SIX10 for Foc indicate monophly. This suggests the core genome of
Foc evolved into a separate lineage after the SIX genes were conserved
within the whole genome. This study is the first to generate SIX12
sequences for Foc, and only from the USA isolates. Interestingly, the
topology of SIX12 suggests polyphyly. The EF-1α, SIX8 and SIX9 gene
topologies support monophyly of Fop. The distinct SIX gene profile and
EF-1α sequence of Fop demonstrates an independent evolutionary origin
from Foc.
